title: Analysis of Youth Risk Behavior
text:
1 Introduction :
We chose this topic because adolescent health behaviors, such as physical activity, sleep patterns, and dietary habits, are critical determinants of long-term health outcomes. Understanding these behaviors provides valuable insights into the factors influencing the well-being of young people, who are at a formative stage of life. By analyzing the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS) dataset, I aim to investigate questions such as: How do physical activity levels vary by age and grade? Are there significant disparities in sleep patterns across demographic groups? What is the relationship between screen time and physical activity levels? This analysis can help identify areas for targeted health interventions and inform policies to promote healthier lifestyles among adolescents, particularly for those who may be at higher risk of adverse health outcomes. For readers unfamiliar with the topic, the YRBSS is a national survey that monitors health-risk behaviors among youth, offering a comprehensive dataset for exploring these crucial questions.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
The dataset originates from the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS), conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The data is in CSV format and contains health-related variables such as physical activity, sleep hours, and screen time. The dataset has approximately 13,500 rows and multiple variables (age, grade, gender, etc.). It was imported into R using the read.csv() function. Some columns contain missing values, which will require cleaning or imputation. The dataset is publicly available on the CDC’s website at YRBSS Data.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis


Code
library(tidyverse)

ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(naniar)   

data <- read.csv("yrbss.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

missing_values <- colSums(is.na(data))
print("Missing Values Per Column:")


[1] "Missing Values Per Column:"


Code
print(missing_values)

Code
gg_miss_var(data) + 
  labs(title = "Missing Values Per Column", x = "Variables", y = "Number of Missing Values")









Code
gg_miss_upset(data)









Code
missing_df <- as.data.frame(missing_values[missing_values > 0], stringsAsFactors = FALSE) %>%
  rownames_to_column(var = "Variable") %>%
  rename(MissingCount = `missing_values[missing_values > 0]`)

ggplot(missing_df, aes(x = reorder(Variable, -MissingCount), y = MissingCount)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Number of Missing Values Per Column", x = "Variable", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()
